intro: Brassica oleracea var. erythrobotrys, commonly known as red cabbage, is a cool-season crop belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its dense, compact head of dark red, purple, or violet-colored leaves, which are rich in anthocyanins. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. Its leaves are edible and commonly used in cooking, while the plant also serves as a host for various pests and diseases. This variety is closely related to other Brassica species, including broccoli and cauliflower.
